line: What is the Cost of Building a Subway?
label: heading

line: Alon Levy
label: paragraph

line: Introduction
label: heading

line: In the 2010s, New York opened two subway extensions (7
label: paragraph

line: extension, Second Avenue Subway) for $1.3-1.6 billion/km.
label: paragraph

line: This decade, Paris has built several M´etro extensions (M4, M12 in
label: paragraph

line: service; M1, M11, GPX under construction) for around $250
label: paragraph

line: million/km.
label: paragraph

line: The most recent Madrid Metro extensions (L2, L9) cost $85
label: paragraph

line: million/km.
label: paragraph

line: The big question: why?
label: paragraph

line: What does this mean?
label: heading

line: New York is planning to have spent around $35 billion between
label: paragraph

line: 2005 and 2030 on subway and commuter rail expansion. But it’s
label: paragraph

line: only getting 15 km of new tunnel!
label: paragraph

line: Paris is spending a similar amount over the same period: e40
label: paragraph

line: billion, for a total of 228 km, 187 underground.
label: paragraph

line: Madrid, a much smaller city, spent e10 billion in 1995-2015 on
label: paragraph

line: 234 km, around 180 underground.
label: paragraph

line: The limiting factor to subway expansion is cost.
label: paragraph

line: Why?
label: heading

line: This is the $2 billion question! The data can help answer
label: paragraph

line: important questions:
label: paragraph

line: Is New York building inherently more diﬃcult projects?
label: paragraph

line: Where else are costs high? Where are they low?
label: paragraph

line: Are high costs caused by geological and geographic factors?
label: paragraph

line: Are deep institutional factors (e.g. health care, legal system)
label: paragraph

line: involved?
label: paragraph

line: Is this about cheaper construction methods?
label: paragraph

line: Can anything be done about the problem?
label: paragraph

line: Good news: it appears the problem is, at least in theory, solvable!
label: paragraph

line: Lit review: cost overruns
label: paragraph

line: There has been extensive study of cost overruns from the initial
label: paragraph

line: budget:
label: paragraph

line: Pickrell 1990, 1992: American urban rail; see more recent
label: paragraph

line: revision by Hardy-Doh-Yuan-Zhou-Button 2009.
label: paragraph

line: Fouracre-Allport-Thomson 1990: developing-world metros.
label: paragraph

line: Flyvbjerg on strategic misrepresentation (i.e. lying):
label: paragraph

line: Flyvbjerg-Bruzelius-Rothengatter’s Megaprojects and Risk
label: paragraph

line: 2003, Flyvberg-Holm-Buhl 2002-5, etc.
label: paragraph

line: These studies ﬁnd that costs tend to run over, but don’t compare
label: paragraph

line: absolute costs. But they give us one caution: we should be wary of
label: paragraph

line: old ex ante data.
label: paragraph

line: Lit review: absolute costs
label: heading

line: Some studies of absolute costs of urban rail:
label: paragraph

line: Flyvbjerg-Bruzelius-van Wee 2008: small N, all in developed
label: paragraph

line: countries, mixed subways/els. This study ﬁnds a small US
label: paragraph

line: premium, but the US lines compared are easier to build than
label: paragraph

line: some of the European lines.
label: paragraph

line: Gordon-Schleicher 2015: bigger N, covering poor and rich
label: paragraph

line: countries, about 1990-2015. They ﬁnd a large US premium
label: paragraph

line: and a small but signiﬁcant positive regression of GDP per
label: paragraph

line: capita on costs.
label: paragraph

line: RPA 2018: several case studies in North America and Europe.
label: paragraph

line: Madrid’s formula
label: paragraph

line: Manuel Melis Maynar was president of Madrid Metro in
label: paragraph

line: 1998-2009. In 2003, he gave a report on how Madrid expanded its
label: paragraph

line: Metro for such low cost:
label: paragraph

line: Contracts are awarded based on a technical score (50%),
label: paragraph

line: speed (20%), and cost (30%).
label: paragraph

line: Designs are streamlined, conservative, and reused between
label: paragraph

line: diﬀerent lines.
label: paragraph

line: Stations are built as shallow as possible.
label: paragraph

line: Contracts are itemized, not awarded by lump sum, so change
label: paragraph

line: orders come pre-negotiated (see also Ryan 2019 on Indian
label: paragraph

line: power plants).
label: paragraph

line: Design and construction are awarded to diﬀerent ﬁrms—no
label: paragraph

line: design-build.
label: paragraph

line: In-house oversight—no consultants.
label: paragraph

line: The data
label: heading

line: The primary source for this talk is a new dataset of diﬀerent urban
label: paragraph

line: rail lines and their costs. Some key attributes:
label: paragraph

line: The table covers 205 distinct items totaling 3,600 km of
label: paragraph

line: urban rail.
label: paragraph

line: About 40 countries are represented. The dataset is fairly
label: paragraph

line: complete in the developed world for lines built since the 1990s
label: paragraph

line: but has gaps elsewhere, especially in China.
label: paragraph

line: Most lines are recent: about 2/3 are still under construction or
label: paragraph

line: in planning, forcing the use of ex ante and in medio sources.
label: paragraph

line: The sources are predominantly popular and trade media, and
label: paragraph

line: secondarily agency plans and public documents.
label: paragraph

line: Figures exclude rolling stock whenever possible.
label: paragraph

line: Important line characteristics
label: heading

line: The data table focuses on cost/km, but mentions three additional
label: paragraph

line: characteristics to avoid confounders:
label: paragraph

line: The proportion of the line that is in tunnel.
label: paragraph

line: Number of stations: stations are a key part of construction
label: paragraph

line: costs, esp. at the high end (about 75% of SAS’s costs).
label: paragraph

line: Whether the line is regional rail (RR) or metro: RR
label: paragraph

line: consistently costs more (RER vs. M´etro, Crossrail vs.
label: paragraph

line: Underground, Gateway/ESA vs. SAS, etc.).
label: paragraph

line: The analysis focuses on metros, since few items in the table are
label: paragraph

line: RR.
label: paragraph

line: Line centrality
label: heading

line: Two additional characteristics, not mentioned in the table:
label: paragraph

line: Line centrality: hard to deﬁne precisely, but tunnels cost more
label: paragraph

line: in city center (inc. RR) than in outlying areas. One potential
label: paragraph

line: metric: number of crossings of older lines.
label: paragraph

line: Construction method: cut-and-cover is cheaper than bored
label: paragraph

line: tunnel with cut-and-cover stations (by a factor of 1.5-2),
label: paragraph

line: which is cheaper than bored tunnel with mined stations. But
label: paragraph

line: this data isn’t available in every city.
label: paragraph

line: These are related: city center costs are higher partly because it’s
label: paragraph

line: harder to cut-and-cover. Paris M1 and M12 extension stations cost
label: paragraph

line: e90 million apiece, but RER E La D´efense is e450 million.
label: paragraph

line: SAS Phase 1 stations were deep-mined at around $750 million
label: paragraph

line: each, but they could have been built as shallow cut-and-cover!
label: paragraph

line: Analysis: preliminary observations
label: paragraph

line: Several preliminary observations:
label: paragraph

line: Costs are citywide, that is similar across subways in the same
label: paragraph

line: city.
label: paragraph

line: Costs are to some extent national, that is similar between
label: paragraph

line: diﬀerent cities in the same country.
label: paragraph

line: Costs are rising: more recent subways in the same city cost
label: paragraph

line: more than older ones.
label: paragraph

line: RR is more expensive than metros.
label: paragraph

line: Because costs are national, the explanation should be institutional
label: paragraph

line: and not geologic or geographic. This is diﬃcult and requires
label: paragraph

line: qualitative research, since N is about 40.
label: paragraph

line: Who’s cheap and who’s expensive?
label: paragraph

line: The Anglosphere is expensive, around $500+ million/km
label: paragraph

line: ex-New York: US, Canada, Australia, Singapore, UK.
label: paragraph

line: Western Europe: Germany and NL cost $300-400 million/km,
label: paragraph

line: France is $250 million/km, Mediterranean and Nordic and
label: paragraph

line: Swiss costs average $90-150 million/km.
label: paragraph

line: Eastern Europe runs the gamut from Romania at $100
label: paragraph

line: million/km to Hungary and Russia circa $500 million/km.
label: paragraph

line: East Asia: Korea is about $100 million/km, China perhaps
label: paragraph

line: $250 million, Taiwan and Japan are expensive.
label: paragraph

line: Ex-colonies: all are expensive—subways tend to run at $500
label: paragraph

line: million/km and Manila has one at $1 billion/km.
label: paragraph

line: Other developing: Turkey averages $100 million/km, Ecuador
label: paragraph

line: and Chile are about $150 million/km, Iran maybe $200
label: paragraph

line: million/km, Mexico and Brazil costlier ($330 million/km in
label: paragraph

line: S˜ao Paulo), Thailand $300-650 million/km.
label: paragraph

line: Costs are rising
label: paragraph

line: For the most part, if there are multiple items in the same city,
label: paragraph

line: more recent ones cost more. Exception: if the most recent items
label: paragraph

line: are suburban extensions and the older line is in city center (e.g.
label: paragraph

line: Warsaw).
label: paragraph

line: This is also true historically. Approximate construction costs per
label: paragraph

line: km, in millions of 2019 dollars:
label: paragraph

line: Era New York
label: paragraph

line: London Paris
label: paragraph

line: But: some places (Canada, Singapore) have had higher recent cost
label: paragraph

line: growth, others less growth (Korea, Spain).
label: paragraph

line: Common but probably wrong explanations
label: heading

line: Standard political institutions don’t seem like good explanations:
label: paragraph

line: Health care costs: the US has expensive health care, but the
label: paragraph

line: UK has a cheap public system and SG has a cheap private one.
label: paragraph

line: Unionization: in developed countries union density correlates
label: paragraph

line: with lower costs thanks to Scandinavia, but really there is not
label: paragraph

line: much correlation either way beyond the fact that the
label: paragraph

line: Anglosphere is expensive.
label: paragraph

line: GDP per capita: unlike in Gordon-Schleicher, the GDP-cost
label: paragraph

line: correlation vanishes if we correct for the tendency of poorer
label: paragraph

line: countries to build more els and fewer subways.
label: paragraph

line: Corruption perception: the cleanest countries include low-cost
label: paragraph

line: Scandinavia and high-cost CA, NL, SG, UK; Europe’s most
label: paragraph

line: corrupt are low-cost ES, GR, IT and high-cost HU, PL, RU.
label: paragraph

line: The Anglosphere premium
label: heading

line: The Anglosphere has several common features, all of which are in
label: paragraph

line: correlation, and therefore correlate with high costs:
label: paragraph

line: Common law. But Qu´ebec has civil law and the same costs as
label: paragraph

line: Toronto.
label: paragraph

line: Winner-take all elections. But New Zealand uses proportional
label: paragraph

line: representation, and Auckland’s City Rail Link is $850
label: paragraph

line: million/km.
label: paragraph

line: High inequality, no collective bargaining. But Canada and
label: paragraph

line: Australia are comparable in inequality to Southern Europe.
label: paragraph

line: What if the cause is not as political? The Anglosphere tends to
label: paragraph

line: mostly learn from other Anglo countries. Maybe the root cause is
label: paragraph

line: lack of knowledge about non-English-speaking practices?
label: paragraph

line: Anglosphere insularity
label: heading

line: Some examples of Anglosphere insularity suggesting the region
label: paragraph

line: does not learn from others, and New York is especially insular:
label: paragraph

line: In SF, oﬃcials at Caltrain and TJPA had no idea Germany
label: paragraph

line: even has commuter rail. One TJPA consultant, re Japanese
label: paragraph

line: designs: “Asians don’t value life the way we do.”
label: paragraph

line: MTA Chair Pat Foye, last week: “New York has a more
label: paragraph

line: built-out commuter rail network than London.”
label: paragraph

line: American conversation on transit reforms (RPA on costs, fare
label: paragraph

line: capping, etc.): references to London, few to none to
label: paragraph

line: Continental Europe or East Asia.
label: paragraph

line: US and Canadian proposals for reform propose more
label: paragraph

line: design-build, the opposite of what Spain and France do.
label: paragraph

line: So what can be done to ﬁx this, concretely?
label: paragraph

line: Synthesis: how New York can reduce costs
label: heading

line: Imitate, don’t innovate!
label: paragraph

line: New York needs to do what the Spaniards and Koreans and
label: paragraph

line: Italians and Swiss and Nordics do, with some sanity-check
label: paragraph

line: assistance from medium-cost countries like France.
label: paragraph

line: This covers diﬀerences in engineering, contracts, and political
label: paragraph

line: institutions.
label: paragraph

line: Build simpler stations
label: heading

line: The cost diﬀerence seems to be mostly in stations.
label: paragraph

line: SAS tunneling and systems together are a factor of 2 over Paris
label: paragraph

line: (and LA has no premium at all), stations are a factor of 4-8
label: paragraph

line: premium. To simplify stations, use the following methods:
label: paragraph

line: Shallow cut-and-cover construction, disrupting the street for
label: paragraph

line: about 18 months. No mining except at undercrossings.
label: paragraph

line: No mezzanines. All circulation, including fare barriers, should
label: paragraph

line: be on the platform level or at street level.
label: paragraph

line: An island platform, ideally accessed from a street median, to
label: paragraph

line: avoid duplicating elevators, stairs, etc.
label: paragraph

line: No signature architecture. Station designs should be reused
label: paragraph

line: systemwide. If art is desired, put on exhibits.
label: paragraph

line: Improve contracting practices
label: heading

line: Rosenthal 2016: contractors say that there is a premium of 30%
label: paragraph

line: just for working with the MTA’s byzantine process, in addition to
label: paragraph

line: any proﬁt margin from lack of competition.
label: paragraph

line: Instead, contracts should be ﬂexible and strictly separate design
label: paragraph

line: and construction. No design-build.
label: paragraph

line: An in-house team should oversee the design and project
label: paragraph

line: management, and have the authority to reject bids. If only
label: paragraph

line: 1-2 contractors bid, restart the bidding process.
label: paragraph

line: Let the designers choose their own materials, methods,
label: paragraph

line: etc.—give them a technical score and make that 50% of the
label: paragraph

line: weight of the bid. Do not blindly award to the lowest bidder.
label: paragraph

line: Standards should be about performance, not methods.
label: paragraph

line: No lump sum contracts. Bills should be itemized to prevent
label: paragraph

line: change order litigation.
label: paragraph

line: Do not privatize the state
label: heading

line: Overheads account for 27% of SAS costs, vs. 15% of Paris M1 and
label: paragraph

line: M14 extensions and 8% of Madrid L9.
label: paragraph

line: Agencies must hire adequate in-house project management, in lieu
label: paragraph

line: of relying on consultants who tend to be less likely to be willing to
label: paragraph

line: take a stand and propose inexpensive but disruptive techniques.
label: paragraph

line: “Disruptive” includes politically disruptive, e.g. forcing diﬀerent
label: paragraph

line: agencies to work together. California HSR is full of agency turf
label: paragraph

line: clashes leading to unnecessary tunnels.
label: paragraph

line: In-house workers tend to cost 1/3 to 1/2 as much as consultants.
label: paragraph

line: In-house engineers and managers must be paid competitively, in
label: paragraph

line: cash and current beneﬁts, not a pension that vests in 23 years.
label: paragraph

line: Further research: ﬁll in gaps in data
label: paragraph

line: The data has signiﬁcant gaps in quantity and quality, and ﬁlling
label: paragraph

line: them is a priority to get a more accurate picture:
label: paragraph

line: Add more current and historic items to the table, esp. in
label: paragraph

line: China, since so much (average-cost) work happens there.
label: paragraph

line: Add more granular information about station vs. tunnel costs,
label: paragraph

line: overheads, environmental review process, etc.
label: paragraph

line: Look at ancillary costs, e.g. elevator retroﬁts for wheelchair
label: paragraph

line: accessibility.
label: paragraph

line: Compare other infrastructure: HSR, electriﬁcation, airports,
label: paragraph

line: highways, water works, sewage—institutional factors should
label: paragraph

line: impact all of these equally.
label: paragraph

line: Further research: comparative institutions
label: heading

line: More granular research on legal, political, etc. institutions should
label: paragraph

line: explain how the US got to this point of being so behind in
label: paragraph

line: infrastructure. Potential examples:
label: paragraph

line: Kagan’s theory of American adversarial legalism vs. European
label: paragraph

line: bureaucratic legalism.
label: paragraph

line: Schleicher’s work on subnational governance and the
label: paragraph

line: American local democratic deﬁcit.
label: paragraph

line: Labor activists’ notion of a siege mentality among unions in
label: paragraph

line: the US (and UK?) leading to resistance to productivity
label: paragraph

line: improvements.
label: paragraph

line: Research on regulatory capture and civil service quality in
label: paragraph

line: comparative politics.
label: paragraph

line: Further research: other methods
label: heading

line: The value of the principles laid out in Melis 2003 suggests that
label: paragraph

line: qualitative methods (e.g. case studies) are of great value.
label: paragraph

line: Preliminary interviews are revealing a wealth of information about
label: paragraph

line: how diﬀerent countries oversee public contracts.
label: paragraph

line: Interviews in Rosenthal 2016 and design standards show some
label: paragraph

line: diﬀerences in staﬃng levels in New York versus Western Europe.
label: paragraph

line: Thank you!
label: heading
